description: Indicates direction, destination, purpose, or time.
explanation:
### Name
- 助詞「に」（方向・目的・時点）

### Meaning and function
- Marks the goal/endpoint of movement (to; into; onto) and direction (toward).
- Marks the purpose of movement with verbs like go/come/return (in order to).
- Marks a specific point in time when something happens (at/on/in).

### Form and templates
- Destination/goal
  - Place N + に + [motion/arrival verb: 行く・来る・帰る・着く・入る など]
  - Direction word (右・左・前・後ろ・北・南 など) + に + [movement/turn verb]
  - Alternative for pure direction only: Place N + へ + [motion verb] (に emphasizes arrival/goal; へ emphasizes direction)
- Purpose of movement
  - N(suru) + (し) に + [行く・来る・帰る・出かける・戻る など]
  - Alternative (very common): V(stem) + に + [movement verb]
  - Restriction: only with verbs of movement/direction
- Time point
  - N(time: specific clock time, day, date, month, year, holiday, weekend) + に + [predicate]
  - Optionality: with days of the week/dates/months, に may be omitted in casual speech; with exact clock times it’s normally used
  - Do not use に with relative-time words (今日・明日・昨日・今・来週・毎日 など), except for special contrastive/emphatic patterns
- Ordering and co-occurrence
  - Time N + に and Place N + に can co-occur in one clause; time generally precedes place (Time に → Place に → verb)
- Conjugation
  - Verbs conjugate as usual (plain/polite, tense, polarity). The particle に itself does not change.

### Usage notes and constraints
- Register/naturalness: Neutral and ubiquitous in all registers; extremely frequent.
- に vs へ (direction): に highlights the arrival/goal or endpoint; へ highlights general direction/path. へ cannot mark time or purpose.
- に vs で (place): に marks destination/arrival or time; で marks the location where an action occurs. Do not use で for destinations or time points.
- Purpose use:
  - Best with V(stem) + に or with suru-nouns plus しに. Not every bare noun works naturally as a “purpose.”
  - For general purpose not tied to movement, use ために or ように instead of に.
- Time use:
  - Use に with specific, countable points on the calendar/clock (3時、月曜日、4月、3日 など).
  - Often omit に after broader periods (朝・昼・夜・週末) in everyday speech unless you want to stress the timing; adding に sounds more formal or deliberate.
  - に marks a point-in-time, not a duration. For “for X time,” use ～間.
  - Ambiguous forms like 三日 can mean “the 3rd (day of month)” or “three days (duration)”; adding に disambiguates it as a date/point-in-time.
- Multiple に in one sentence is fine as each に attaches to its own noun (e.g., time に + place に).

### Common mistakes (optional, only if relevant)
- Using で instead of に for destinations or time points.
- Adding に to relative-time words (今日・明日・毎日 など) where it is normally not used.
- Using へ for purpose or time (へ cannot express these).
- Using Nに + movement verb for purpose with a noun that is not an action; prefer V(stem) に or suru-noun + しに.
- Using に to mark durations (三時間に勉強する × for “study for three hours”); use ～間 instead.

### Related grammar (optional, only if relevant)
- へ: Direction/path only; weaker sense of “to/toward” than に; cannot mark time or purpose.
- で: Location of action; contrasts with に which marks destination/arrival or time.
- ために: General “in order to/for the sake of”; usable without movement; broader than purpose に.
- ように: Purpose/aim for achieving a state or ability; often with potential/imperative nuances; not restricted to movement.
- まで／までに／から: Time and place boundaries (“until/as far as,” “by,” “from”); combine with に for “by [time]” (までに).

examples.jp: 三時に起きる。
examples.en: I get up at three.

examples.jp: 月曜日に図書館に行かない。
examples.en: I don’t go to the library on Monday.

examples.jp: 2024年に大学を卒業した。
examples.en: I graduated from university in 2024.

examples.jp: 九時に会社に着きましたか。
examples.en: Did you arrive at the office at nine?

examples.jp: 犬が庭に来た。
examples.en: A dog came into the yard.

examples.jp: 角で右に曲がってください。
examples.en: Please turn right at the corner.

examples.jp: 北に向かいましたか。
examples.en: Did you head north?

examples.jp: 机の下に入らなかった。
examples.en: I didn’t go under the desk.

examples.jp: 私は学校に行きません。
examples.en: I will not go to school.

examples.jp: パンを買いにコンビニに行く。
examples.en: I’m going to the convenience store to buy bread.

examples.jp: 運動しに公園へ行きませんか。
examples.en: Shall we go to the park to exercise?

examples.jp: 資料を取りにオフィスに戻った。
examples.en: I went back to the office to pick up the documents.

examples.jp: 写真を撮りに海に来なかった。
examples.en: I didn’t come to the beach to take photos.

examples.jp: 朝七時に駅に友だちを迎えに行きます。
examples.en: I’ll go to the station at 7 a.m. to pick up a friend.

examples.jp: 祝日に祖父母の家に行った。
examples.en: I went to my grandparents’ house on the holiday.

examples.jp: 三日に市役所に申請しに行きました。
examples.en: I went to city hall on the 3rd to submit an application.

examples.jp: 危ないので、前に出ないでください。
examples.en: It’s dangerous, so please don’t step forward.

examples.jp: 電車は次の駅に止まりません。
examples.en: The train does not stop at the next station.

examples.jp: 今朝八時に市役所に着いたのは私だ。
examples.en: The one who arrived at city hall at eight this morning was me.

examples.jp: あなたは左に曲がりますか。
examples.en: Do you turn left?

negativeExamples.jp: 勉強のために図書館へ行った。
negativeExamples.en: I went to the library to study.
I asked the teacher a question.

negativeExamples.jp: 静かに歩いてください。
春になると、山は桜でいっぱいだ。
negativeExamples.en: When spring comes, the mountains are full of cherry blossoms.

negativeExamples.jp: 東京にて会議を行います。
negativeExamples.en: We will hold a meeting in Tokyo.

negativeExamples.jp: 日本に関する本を探しています。
negativeExamples.en: I’m looking for books about Japan.

negativeExamples.jp: 子ども向けに作られた動画です。
negativeExamples.en: It’s a video made for children.

negativeExamples.jp: 家族に会えてうれしかった。
negativeExamples.en: I was happy to see my family.
